review: A Working Man (2025) Deserved a Better Edition Since It Is Overlong (11,698 ‚Äì17 May 2025 ‚Äì by Claudio Carvalho) In Chicago, the former British military Levon Cade (Jason Statham) works at a construction company as foreman. He has a daughter, Merry Cade (Isla Gie), that is under the custody of his father-in-law Dr. Jordan Roth (Richard Heap), who hates him since Levon‚Äôs wife committed suicide. He considers the owner of the construction company, Joe Garcia (Michael Pe√±a), his wife Carla (Noemi Gonzalez) and their daughter Jenny (Arianna Rivas) as his family. When Jenny completes the first semester of her university, she celebrates with her friends in a bar. Out of the blue, the Russian traffickers Viper (Emmett J Scanlan) and Artemis (Eve Mauro) kidnaps her. The police do not find any clue to Jenny and Joe and Carla offer US$ 70,000.00 to Levon to find Jenny, but he refuses. He visits his blind friend Gunny Lefferty (David Harbour), who lives with his wife in the woods, and he says that Levon should help Joe‚Äôs family. Now Levon goes to the bar where Jenny was to look for evidence. Then he follows the bartender Johnny (David Witts) to his home to learn what happened to Jenny, and soon he learns that the Russian mafia is involved, in the beginning of the dangerous journey of Levon to rescue Jenny. ‚ÄúA Working Man‚Äù (2025) is an action movie by David Ayer with Jason Statham, presently the best actor of action films. The plot is unoriginal, with the ‚Äúhero‚Äù helping his friends to retrieve their daughter that was abducted by Russian mobsters but is also too long with almost 2 hours running time (1 h 56 min to be more precise). Consequently, there are a great number of gangsters with Russian names difficult to recall sometimes who is who. One question, why after rescuing Jenny, Levon leaves the powerful weapon provided by Gunny on the pool table to be burnt? My vote is six. Jason Statham reunites with director David Ayer in *A Working Man*, a gritty action-thriller that delivers the expected punches but stumbles in its execution. Statham portrays Levon Cade, a former Royal Marine turned construction worker, who is thrust back into a world of violence when his boss's daughter is kidnapped. The film attempts to blend high-octane action with emotional depth, exploring themes of redemption and fatherhood. While the action sequences are intense and showcase Statham's prowess, the film suffers from a disjointed narrative and underdeveloped characters. Critics have noted that the movie "falls short due to a disjointed and inconsistent narrative" , and that it "lacks urgency and coherence" . Despite these shortcomings, some viewers may appreciate the film's attempt to delve deeper into its protagonist's psyche. In summary, "A Working Man" offers the familiar thrills of a Statham-led action film but doesn't quite rise above its genre conventions.

I was a HUGE FAN of The Beekeeper for it's B-Tier Cheesey Action & Antics, and Taken is "One Of My ABSOLUTE FAVORITE Action Movies Of All Times". Unfortunately, that doesn't guarantee you'll enjoy this film that is essentially those two films roled into one. This film struggles to balance the "Campy Style" with "Serious Action". The script itself could have used a few more drafts, especially with plot beats that feel like they're going no where and dialogue that is hard to follow at points. Also, Jason Statham's character and the girl he is trying to save both have WAY TOO MUCH PLOT ARMOR!!! At points, it seems like the bullets are swerving around him when he's in a narrow field of sight for the bad guys to shoot him, and if you remember what they said in Taken about the time-table with trafficing women, this girl should already be LONG GONE or DEAD. She's taken on a Friday night, and for some odd reason her family waits until Monday Morning to ask their friend for help, knowing his skill set. At other points, the girl pulls stunts that should be getting her executed on the spot, especially when it's established that the group owns a Clean-Up Crew, but they have to wait till late at night to try and take her far away to put her down, giving Levon Cade plenty of time to save her. Some have stated this might have worked better as a mini-series on TV and I have to agree with them. This movie isn't making me want to head straight back to see it again, and the more I think about it, the more problems I find with it. The action is still cool, and there's some funny moments here and there, but they also constantly set up moments that don't go where they CLEARLY SHOULD GO, Including with Levon's daughter. You can wait to stream this or just skip it all together. C+ & 6.2/10

A Working Man is the cinematic equivalent of a shrug‚Äîuninspired, clumsy, and bafflingly pointless. It's not just that the acting is wooden; it's that it feels like no one involved even read the script past page two. Stallone, wearing both the writer and producer hats, manages to deliver a screenplay so disjointed it makes a late-night infomercial look like The Godfather. The plot lurches from scene to scene with no logic or purpose, stitched together with tired tropes and dialogue that sounds like it was lifted from a parody. Jason Statham, normally a reliable presence in action roles, sleepwalks through the film like he‚Äôs counting down the minutes until he can fire his agent. Even the action scenes, which should at least be entertaining, are painfully staged and bizarrely edited‚Äîas if someone dared the crew to shoot everything in one take and call it a day. The costumes? Distracting. The tone? All over the place. The end result? A film that confuses volume with intensity and pacing with chaos. This isn‚Äôt just a bad movie. It‚Äôs a wasted opportunity‚Äîand a reminder that even big names can churn out bafflingly bad content when there‚Äôs no one brave enough to say, ‚ÄúMaybe we shouldn‚Äôt.‚Äù

Ahhh yes. The newest Jason Statham film in which he plays a former soldier/spy who tries to live a quiet life and escape his violent past; but gets drawn back in after somebody kills or kidnaps his loved one. Ladies and gentlemen this is A Working Man to a tee. Last year he was a Beekeeper, this year he‚Äôs a construction worker. In all seriousness, A Working Man is an ok film. It isn‚Äôt terrible like some folks are saying, there are bright spots in the film. But it does suffer from lackluster filmmaking that makes it very forgettable. It‚Äôs almost a perfect mixture that makes the film ok, kind of like mixing the weird drink combinations. You think it will taste bad, but it actually doesn‚Äôt taste that bad but you wouldn‚Äôt have it again. Starting with the performances, they were ok. The cast knew the roles they were given and just played their roles. Jason Statham does an ok job. He knows the assignment and what type of character to play so it worked for him in A Working Man. What also worked for the film was the action. The action in the film was fun. It was able to keep the viewers attention from when an action sequence began to when it ended. I will say out of all the recent Statham action films, this one I felt had the least amount. But it made up for it when the scenes came up. The last two aspects of the film to talk about in a combined manner is both the writing and runtime. The writing in the film is its biggest hindrance. It feels very first draft and you can tell because it hits every beat we see in any other action film. From the beginning of the film all the way to the end, you will guess almost everything that is going to happen. Which is fine, because you‚Äôre not going into this expecting Oscar worthy writing. But on the other hand, the writing could‚Äôve been tightened up because there is no way this film should clock in at 1hr and 56 minutes! It is crazy to me that this is almost a two hour film. But on the other hand, not really because it felt like it was almost 2 hours and was dragging along in the middle and towards the end. 25-30 minutes could‚Äôve been cut to have it by about 90 minutes. Overall, A Working Man is a serviceable action film. I wouldn‚Äôt say not to watch it, but I feel it‚Äôll be a watch when it hits streaming later in the spring than in theaters. But if there is one thing to take away from its release, it beat Snow White in its opening weekend. That‚Äôll be the description on the Blu-Ray copy.

When I tell you about a movie where Jason Statham takes on human traffickers, you know exactly what you‚Äôre getting yourself into. The movie is A WORKING MAN, reuniting Statham and director David Ayers just one year after working together on THE BEEKEEPER, which I loved. Based on the book Levon‚Äôs Trade by Chuck Dixon, this tells the simple story of Levon Cade (Jason Statham), a former Royal Marine Commando who‚Äôs now a foreman of a construction company. He works for Joe Garcia (Michael Pe√±a) and his wife Carla (Noemi Gonzalez) and daughter Jenny (Arianna Rivas). Jenny gets‚Ä¶‚Ä¶taken‚Ä¶‚Ä¶and you know the rest. This movie tries to have a JOHN WICK approach to world-building, where there‚Äôs an underground network of baddies pulling the strings, but they cram way too many of them in. The further up the bad guy chain we go, the more cartoony they get. One guy literally looked like the Penguin with his top hat and sculpted cane. When the movie was leaning in on the silly fun pow bang boom that Statham is now known for, I was having lots of fun. Statham has this thing down to a science by now, but this one just feels more repetitive and generic than usual. For me, the sillier and more outlandish the better. Don‚Äôt take yourself too seriously. This is why I loved THE BEEKEEPER. This action movie might not be unique enough for me these days, but I still had myself a good time and I think you will too if you turn your brain off. There are more books that A WORKING MAN is based on, so I wouldn‚Äôt be surprised if we see Statham‚Äôs Levon Cade again.

**2/5 - Statham Deserved Better** As a longtime Statham fan, I went in hoping for another gritty ride like *The Beekeeper*‚Äîwhich, while not perfect, at least had some sting. *The Working Man* (ironic title for how lazy the script felt) plays like a discount *Taken* knockoff, with none of the urgency or emotional pull. The plot's thinner than a gas station sandwich, and I‚Äôve seen more compelling villains in a Saturday morning cartoon. Every henchman felt ripped from a ‚Äúbad guy starter pack.‚Äù I don‚Äôt mind a brainless action flick now and then, but this one didn‚Äôt even try to entertain. Not asking for Shakespeare here, but at least give me a reason to care who‚Äôs getting punched. Even Statham, usually a reliable tough guy anchor, felt wasted. By the third act, I was more invested in checking the time than in any character‚Äôs fate. File this under "forgettable."
